Mr. Biggs, your argument about Social Security being part of a unified budget is exactly what is wrong with the budget process in Washington.  It should not be part of some grand unified budget given that it has its own revenue stream and expenditures.  I agree with but one statement, it must be fixed either by increasing revenue or decreasing expenditures or more appropriately, both.  Your last paragraph is where you gave yourself away with false data.  I know of no rational person arguing to keep social security talks separate is  pushing reform off the table and in fact, the exact opposite is true.  Perhaps you should stop listening to talk radio and opinion shows that make this false claim about reform and talk to people other than in your own echo chamber.

I look forward to your humorous history of "gerrymandered" Congressional districts. It seems that now there are only 3 dozen House seats in competition. This causes strange effects, e.g. Democrats received more votes but the House majority is Republican! I am also interested in your take on how effective former members of Congress and Civil Servants are as lobbyists. Today, I listened to the former head of DARPA on public radio talk about "geeks" from her new perch at Google. She was charming but it makes one wonder if the "free" enterprise system is "gerrymandering" itself into monopolies based on their effective investment in lobbying. Can a modest income inventor gain a toehold in the U.S. free market? It is my understanding that Tesla, a recipient of the prestigious Franklin Award, died a reclusive pauper in a Manhattan hotel. My colleagues, Dr. James Powell & Gordon Danby, also Franklin Medal awardees, invented superconducting Maglev transport in 1966. The US cancelled Maglev R&D in 1975 & their Maglev was developed by Japan. The 300 mph Japanese Maglev was admired by President Obama when he introduced the High Speed Intercity Pasenger Rail program on April 16, 2009, saying, "So It's being done; It's just not being done here." Of course, we notified the President that the inventors were still working & had developed an even more capable system. No response but we continue to write because this low-cost energy efficient, green system is inevitable.

In the United States children caught up in the Juvenile Justice system often pay a lifetime price for crimes they committed while young. This was not always the case.Not that long ago when a child reached the age of 18 their record/crimes were erased.
Now many crimes are considered a felony and hold a lifelong brand on a person. There are many young adults that will always struggle to find job or even a place to stay due to something stupid they once did while young. There are stories of young men that had consensual relationships with their girlfriends, often just a year younger than themselves. They became branded as sex offenders because the girl was 15 or 16. Branded for life with a web announcement that they are a sexual predator. Courts, and the public, seem unwilling to consider the whole picture in these cases and because children do not have the same rights as adults rarely do they have their case heard in a just manner and journalistic oversight is thwarted to 'protect the rights of the child', while in reality, the lack of oversight and public exposure had created a very unjust and destructive environment for our children.
Returning to a more protective stance on the future hope for our children, is a good thing. Thanks for bringing this issue forward for discussion.

You know Texas has threatened to secede from the Union.  Not a bad idea!  May I suggest that USA citizens demand that the state of South Carolina secede!

Mark Sanford has promised not to run if his ex-wife, Jenny Sanford gets in the race. But what we are witnessing in South Carolina is a sea-change, instructive as a forewarning to the rest of America. From Cole Blease, who publicly advocated lynching, to Strom Thurmond (and Cotton Ed Smith who opposed women voting in between), South Carolina's senators and national leaders wielded power and called their own shots. Any plans within the state, sometimes the nation, were approved by them; they marched to their own tune. (Who remembers Thurmond foiling Abe Fortas' Supreme Court nomination by setting up closed screenings of adult films in the Capitol to review Fortas' community standards? Or Thurmond wrestling a senator outside of a hearing room, the winner getting to vote? Or him reading his grandmother's biscuit recipe into the record in the Senate's longest filibuster? Or him invoking cloture when NC's Jesse Helms tried to filibuster the King Holiday Bill? Or Thurmond tanking Reagan's first run at the GOP nomination at the convention?)

Today's crew, through reactionary, follow marching orders; they are told what to do by an elite, monied, inter-networked cabal. (Since when do 6 SC representatives worry more about budget deficits than tax cuts puting money in the hands of a state 47th in income?) Their ideology is the beck and call of the oligarchs.Thurmond got paid. These guys are bought. Money trumped power. Ol' Strom would have never let that happen. Power was his coin.

Ashley... I'm having a hard time deciphering your point. No matter how many calender months the MLS season runs, respective to the NBA season, for purposes of attendance, the best way to compare the two is by the number of games played. Even if you want to add the odd non-league match, MLS teams don't come anywhere close to playing 82 games per season. The key point being that a comparison of average attendance figures skews in favor of the MLS with it's greater seating capacity per game, and in favor of the NBA if one were to use total attendance over the course of a season... for obvious reasons.

@George... Great point about "concentration" and by extension, dilution. I'm not even sure how many pro teams there are in Rome, but there are two (Lazio and Roma) just in Serie A, same for Milan, Manchester, London (Tottenham, Chelsea, QPR, Arsenal, West Ham, Fulham... all in the PL alone). Clearly there'll be some crowd dilution there relative to say Sporting KC :)

Paul, your point still isn't lost though, the attendance figures relative to Ligue 1 and the Eredivisie is quite impressive.

@George: The issue with concentration is that, unlike Italy, Spain and England, some of the other countries don't have that issue. France is a huge country in area compared to Italy or England, yet Paris is perhaps the only European Capital with only one top flight team, and PSG's following has been inconsistent, at best. France's "biggest" and best teams have long been from the secondary cities, but there's no major competition for Olympique Lyonnais, for Girondins Bordeaux, and Montpelier and Nice are down the road quite a bit from Olympique Marseille.
Again. Germany has so many huge stadia, and even in relatively small cities like Leverkusen and Moenchengladbach, the regular attendance is astonishing in comparison to the population of those cities.
It's not like Milan is too small a city to fully support two top teams, or Torino, for that matter. Rome is plenty big for two teams. London has six in the top flight, and a bunch more in lower divisions, and there's little difficulty filling the stadia. I don't think that the two teams in Sheffield had any trouble filling good size stadia back when they were both competitive in the Prem, not bouncing back and forth between the Championship and Division One. Any trouble filling OT with 75K and the Etihad with 47K almost every time out?
Certainly more of an issue on our side of the pond.

"Although M.L.S. television ratings continue to be measured in tenths of ratings points, the league’s average attendance last year (18,807) was a league record and was higher than the numbers for the N.B.A. and the N.H.L."

This is misleading because juxtaposed with the television ratings, it is being offered as proof of the league's popularity and the casual observer might be tempted to conclude that there is greater interest by fans in seeing the MLS product live versus the NBA.

While it is difficult to divine fans interest in a sport from mere ticket sales, the simple fact is that basketball/hockey arenas are almost uniformly smaller than soccer stadiums. MSG for instance has a basketball capacity of just over 19,000 and a hockey capacity of just over 18,000. Red Bulls arena in contrasts seats 25,000 at full capacity. So clearly MLS matches have the potential to draw a larger crowd than any NBA/NHL game can.

So while it may be true, and a good omen for the sport that MLS averages 18,807 in attendance per game, the stat about NBA/NHL attendance is being offered out of context. Think of it this way, it would similarly be misleading to offer total attendance numbers as a gauge of the relative viability of each sport, when the NBA season is more than twice as long as the MLS season. It is ironic then to complain about it being unfair to compare the MLS with other sports more than a century in existence, when the writer turns around and does the very same thing.

Meet Sue. Isn’t she sweet?

Sue is the nickname given to the largest, most extensive and best preserved Tyrannosaurus rex specimen ever found. It has a length of 43.5, stands 14 feet tall at the hips, and is estimated to have weighed more than 7 short tons (6.4 t) when alive. It was discovered in the summer of 1990 by Sue Hendrickson, a paleontologist, and was named after her. The fossil was auctioned in October 1997 for $7.6 million, the highest amount ever paid for a dinosaur fossil, and is now a permanent feature at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, Illinois.

Why Sue (besides 50A)? Because she is one for the ages.

If the drinks were sugar-sweetened we might be better off. At the root of a lot of the problems you mention is corn. When Earl Butz imagined corn "fencerow to fencerow" across the U.S. he could not have foreseen the havoc it would wreak. Corn monoculture is disastrous for the environment, as are the multitude of ways people have dreamed up to use the over-abundance that results - CAFOs for animals that don't even eat corn, high fructose corn syrup, ethanol from corn which requires as much energy to produce as can be obtained from the fuel, to name just a few. The big agra corn business benefits few, but has harmed farmers, the land, the waterways, and the people. Dismantling it is the way to "un-invent this food system."

Ms. Regas -- Yes, good points. That does address it, which I felt lacking in the editorial. You don't know any better than I do if either is true, but you make a good point that decent leadership ought to have options for either problem other than just going home.

However, the NYT can fairly be tasked to report if these things are true.

Was it doubled by pork? Did the GOP demand cuts as a price for emergency assistance? When the NYT weighs in, it really can call on the resources to tell us.

If they are lying again, then their noses can be rubbed in it, and the editorial would be stronger.

If either of these things are true, then they can make a reasoned suggestion for better leadership along the lines you suggest.

I expect that from the NYT on a matter of real importance such as this.

Means testing Social Security is not a good idea. Wealthy Americans make up a very small portion of the population, so disqualifying them from receiving Social Security will not make much of an impact on the program’s finances. Over time, the threshold for collecting benefits would end up being lowered. It would convert Social Security into a welfare program and undermine support for it.

There is another trillion or so out there in revenues via cuts in tax expenditures, limiting deductions for the wealthy and closing loopholes - those can be bought for a reduction in the corporate tax rate. At least many businesses put their retained earnings into job creation - not offshore accounts and trusts. If the wealthy think they are not taking more hits they are delusional.

If Republicans want to see anything like a $3-4 trillion dollar deal it is not going to get done with the measly $600 billion just raised. That was more symbolic than anything.

On the spending side - I cannot see Obama making any serious cuts in Medicare and SS if the defense budget is not also cut. And there also will be pain for the well off in terms of using means testing for SS - and perhaps even Medicare.

At the end of the day we need about $4 trillion in cuts and revenues with about $600 billion in spending over 10 years as a down payment on infrastructure improvements that will create jobs.

Everyone will get their pound of flesh but at least there will be some balance which is far better than the plutocratic moves Romney would have made.

Scary to think how close we came to continuing the downward slide of the middle and working class that has been going on for 30 years.
